content.value_statement: Developers need consistent styling patterns for Tailwind CSS components. This skill provides clear rules for using Tailwind directives, custom utilities, and component organization to maintain clean and maintainable stylesheets.
actual_capabilities: Apply Tailwind CSS directives (apply, @layer, @utility, @variant) for component styling
Organize styles in separate CSS files using @layer components for parent-child element styling
Create new components in the designated src/components directory
Follow project-specific file structure rules (avoid modifying src/components/ui)
limitations: Does not install or configure Tailwind CSS - assumes Tailwind is already set up
Does not generate complete components - only provides styling guidelines
Does not validate CSS output or catch styling errors

use_cases.title: New Component Styling
use_cases.description: When creating a new UI component, use Tailwind CSS directives to define consistent, reusable styles in a separate CSS file.

use_cases.title: Custom Utility Creation
use_cases.description: Add custom utilities and variants to components using @utility and @variant directives for project-specific styling needs.
use_cases.target_user: Developers extending Tailwind with custom CSS

use_cases.title: Legacy Code Migration
use_cases.description: Migrate existing CSS to use Tailwind v4 patterns following project conventions for layer organization and class detection.
use_cases.target_user: Developers updating stylesheets to Tailwind v4

prompt_templates.title: Basic Component Styling
prompt_templates.prompt: Style a new [COMPONENT_NAME] component using Tailwind CSS. Create a separate CSS file and use the @layer components directive. Use nested classes for parent-child element styling.

prompt_templates.title: Custom Utility Definition
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a custom utility called [UTILITY_NAME] to [COMPONENT_FILE] using the @utility directive. Make it responsive and include proper documentation comments.

prompt_templates.title: Variant Creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a custom variant called [VARIANT_NAME] in [COMPONENT_FILE] using the @variant directive. Define what selector or state triggers this variant.

prompt_templates.title: Component Organization Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review the styling in [COMPONENT_PATH] and refactor it to follow Tailwind v4 best practices. Ensure @layer components is used correctly and nested classes are properly structured.

output_examples.input: Style a button component with hover and focus states
Add a custom utility for truncate with max-width

best_practices: Always create a separate CSS file for component styling rather than mixing classes inline
Use @layer components to organize styles and enable proper cascade ordering
Follow the project structure: create new components in src/components, never modify src/components/ui
anti_patterns: Mixing inline Tailwind classes with custom CSS in the same file without using @apply
Modifying shared UI components in src/components/ui for custom styling
Skipping the @layer directive and defining styles at the root level

faq.question: What is the @apply directive?
faq.answer: @apply allows you to use existing Tailwind utility classes inside custom CSS rules, combining the power of utilities with semantic class names.

faq.question: When should I use @layer components?
faq.answer: Use @layer components to group custom component styles. This ensures proper precedence over utilities but keeps stylesheet organization clear.

faq.question: What is the difference between @utility and @apply?
faq.answer: @utility creates new Tailwind-style utility classes, while @apply reuses existing utilities within custom CSS rules.

faq.question: Can I use nested CSS with Tailwind?
faq.answer: Yes, Tailwind v4 supports nested CSS naturally. Use nesting inside @layer components to style child elements without repetitive parent selectors.

faq.question: Where should I create new components?
faq.answer: Create new components in src/components directory. Never modify files in src/components/ui as those are shared UI components.

faq.question: Do I need to read the context files for every Tailwind task?
faq.answer: The skill references Tailwind v4 context files for advanced patterns. For basic styling, you can proceed with standard directives. Refer to context files when implementing custom styles, utilities, or variants.
